instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.AP_RESET_L: What is AP_RESET_L? AP_RESET_L resets the wifi hardware when it is low, which will keep it from working. AP_RESET_L needs to be high for reset to not be asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No backlight
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a with short on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>, i was find and take out the shorted cap, now there is no short but at diode mode with good board the caps should be 1168 and its show 350-450, what can cause the problem?
thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No backlight
threads.message: Did you measure on both boards with red probe at ground?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No backlight
threads.message: Yes i did..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No backlight
threads.message:
Compare board readings in the same condition; both w/, or w/o LCD connected.
Lift <DIODE>D8410</DIODE> and check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No backlight
threads.message:
the same...
good board "naked" 1140
bad board "naked" (without <DIODE>D8410</DIODE> and without the shorted cap) 450

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No backlight
threads.message: Compare the readings inverting multimeter probes too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No backlight
threads.message:
good board - no reading 
bad board - 550

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No backlight
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R8431</RESISTOR> has high ohm value, but you can test removing it.
You can completely discard <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> in this way.

I personally bet for one of filter caps, or LCD connector.
There is a "chance" for leakage between copper layers too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No backlight
threads.message:
i was remove <RESISTOR>R8431</RESISTOR> it give 1ohm..
i will try to take each filter out and check..the wired is..after i was disable the short it give me 1140 like the good board, and after i was put "new"filter from other board its show the 550-450

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No backlight
threads.message: it was one of the filters.. :)

Check around <CHIP>U3750</CHIP>/60/70.
Inspect all BT related resistors.

I was thinking that is the problem...

Be sure all resistors from the area are good.
